content.text: Insider threat awareness in our team isn't about suspicion or paranoia. It's about helping each other stay secure and catching accidents before they become incidents.

content.title: What Are Insider Threats?
content.text: An insider threat is when someone with legitimate access to our systems accidentally or intentionally causes a security incident. At ClearTriage, we're focused on the "accidentally" part - because that's what actually happens 99% of the time.

content.title: The Reality: Most Incidents Are Accidents

content.text: Most data breaches involve human error rather than malicious intent. Common accidents include:

items: Sending a document to the wrong email address
Clicking on a phishing link when you're tired or distracted
Forgetting to log out of AWS when working from a coffee shop
Accidentally deleting important files in Google Drive
Sharing credentials to "help out" when someone's locked out

content.text: We've all been there. The key is creating an environment where we can catch these mistakes quickly and fix them without judgment.
If you notice something unusual - whether it's your own mistake or something that seems off - report it to Pete or Dave. Here's what to watch for:

items: **Your own mistakes**: "Oops, I think I clicked a phishing link" or "I may have sent that file to the wrong person"
**Technical oddities**: Unexpected system behavior, files appearing or disappearing, unusual login notifications
**Access concerns**: Someone asking for access they shouldn't need, or you accidentally gaining access to something you shouldn't see
**Behavioral changes**: This is rare in our team, but if someone's acting very differently and it's affecting security practices

content.text: Remember: Reporting your own mistake immediately can turn a potential incident into a non-issue. Quick action is always better than hoping no one notices.
ClearTriage has a strict no-retaliation policy for security reporting. This means:

items: **No punishment for honest mistakes** - We all make them
**No blame culture** - We focus on fixing the issue, not finding fault
**Confidential handling** - Reports are handled discreetly
**Learning opportunities** - Incidents help us improve our processes

content.text: Pete and Dave are your primary contacts for any security concerns. They're here to help, not to judge.

items: **Immediate concerns**: Call or Slack Pete/Dave right away
**Non-urgent observations**: Send an email or bring it up in your next check-in
**Not sure if it matters?**: Report it anyway - better safe than sorry

content.title: Real Example
content.content: "Hey Pete, I got a weird email that looked like it was from AWS but something seemed off. I didn't click anything, but wanted to let you know in case others got it too."

content.text: Here's how we can help each other stay secure:

items: **Double-check before sending**: "Hey, is this the right email for that document?"
**Speak up about phishing**: "Did anyone else get this weird email?"
**Remind about best practices**: "Don't forget to log out of AWS!"
**Share close calls**: "I almost clicked on that link - watch out for emails from..."

content.title: Remember
content.text: We're not looking for insider threats - we're looking out for each other. The goal is preventing accidents and catching them quickly when they happen.

items: Most security incidents are accidents, not malicious acts
Report anything unusual to Pete or Dave - no judgment
Quick reporting turns big problems into small ones
We have an open door policy with zero retaliation

content.text: This isn't about creating a culture of suspicion - it's about creating a culture where we're comfortable admitting mistakes and looking out for each other.
